Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Christine Lee is "The colored Jones polynomial and surfaces in link complements." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Texas at Austin, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Cameron Gordon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific problems investigated by the PI lie at the intersection of quantum topology, hyperbolic geometry, and geometric topology. These are three major approaches to the study of 3-manifolds, which concerns the space of the universe that we live in. The project explores possible relationships between invariants of knots in 3-spaces inspired by ideas in quantum physics, those inspired by putting a hyperbolic metric on the complement of the knot, and the point of view of geometric topology, which studies embedded surfaces in the complement of a knot. 

The fellowship has provided the opportunity for the PI to study with experts in geometric topology at the University of Texas at Austin. This collaboration has resulted in several publications and expanded the scope of connections between geometric topology and quantum topology, primarily through progress on the Slope Conjecture, which closely ties the theory of essential surfaces to an important quantum invariant called the colored Jones polynomial. In addition, the PI has also proved a conjecture by Rozansky concerning the stability behaviors of the categorification of the colored Jones polynomial. 

As part of the broader impacts of the project the PI has mentored two undergraduate students at the University of Texas at Austin through the Directed Reading Program, one of which has gone on to a prestigious graduate program. The PI has also given mathematical presentations to the Austin community in public outreach efforts.
